title: François-Saturnin Lascaris d'Urfé
text:
François-Saturnin Lascaris d'Urfé, S.S. (1641 – June 30, 1701) was a <a href="French%20people">French</a> <a href="Sulpician">Sulpician</a> priest known as the first resident <a href="pastor">pastor</a> of the <a href="parish">parish</a> of Saint-Louis-du-Haut-de-l'Île (in what is now the town of <a href="Baie-D%27Urf%C3%A9">Baie-D'Urfé</a>) on the <a href="Island%20of%20Montreal">Island of Montreal</a> in <a href="New%20France">New France</a>.
Life and career.
Born to a prominent French noble family, Lascaris d'Urfé was a brother of Louis Lascaris d'Urfé, <a href="Count">Count</a> of Sommaviva, whose son was Louis Lascaris d'Urfé, <a href="Bishop%20of%20Limoges">Bishop of Limoges</a>. He held the title of <a href="Marquis">Marquis</a> de Baugé and was also <a href="Abb%C3%A9">Abbé</a> of <a href="Ard%C3%A8che">Ardèche</a>. In 1660, he was admitted to the seminary of Saint-Sulpice in Paris, and ordained in 1665. He was sent as a missionary to <a href="New%20France">New France</a> in 1668. 
In 1669, he accompanied his cousin, <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20de%20Salignac%20de%20la%20Mothe-F%C3%A9nelon%20%28missionary%29">François de Salignac de la Mothe-Fénelon</a>, to the Iroquois mission at <a href="Prince%20Edward%20County%2C%20Ontario">Kenté</a>, on Lake Ontario. In 1672, Fenelon was to establish an Algonquin mission on the outskirts of <a href="Fort%20Ville-Marie">Ville-Marie</a> at a place called <a href="Dorval">Gentilly</a>. Lascaris d'Urfé replaced his cousin there in 1674. His support for Fénelon gave rise to his own problems with <a href="Louis%20de%20Buade%20de%20Frontenac">Governor Frontenac</a>. He accompanied back to France, where he wrote to Minister of Finance <a href="Jean-Baptiste%20Colbert">Jean-Baptiste Colbert</a>, whose daughter-in-law was Lascaris d'Urfé's first cousin, of his mail being opened and other slights.
Lascaris d'Urfé returned to Quebec in 1686, and soon after re-joined the Sulpicians at Montreal. He then founded the mission of Saint-Louis-du-Haut-de-l'Île in the west end of Montreal Island at Pointe-Caron (site of the present-day Baie-D'Urfé Yacht Club). It was a small community of settlers, soldiers, traders, and Indians. At that time, the mission included the entire area from the tip of Montreal Island to Pointe-Claire, Île Perrot, Soulanges, Vaudreuil, and Île aux Tourtes. The mission was attacked by the Iroquois in 1687. The town of <a href="Baie-D%27Urf%C3%A9">Baie-D'Urfé</a> is named after l'Abbé d'Urfé.
After serving in Canada for 19 years, he returned to Paris in 1687 to deal with family matters. He was later appointed as the <a href="Dean%20%28religion%29">Dean</a> of <a href="Le%20Puy%20Cathedral">Cathédrale Notre-Dame</a> in <a href="Puy-en-Velay">Puy-en-Velay</a>, France. Lascaris d'Urfé retired to his château of Baugé, where he died in 1701.
